pr_title: Timelimiter metrics/events: Register timeouts as timeouts and all other exceptions as errors

timeline.message: Consider timeouts as timeouts and errors as errors
Add tests to check if timeLimiter publishes expected events (success, timeout, error)

timeline.bodyText:
Would it even make sense to rethrow a  TimeoutException? That means:  Map a kotlinx.coroutines.TimeoutCancellationException to a java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException?
It might solve the following issue -> #1123
timeline.author: RobWin

replies.bodyText:
The nesting part in Kotlin is indeed a problem. It's something that I solved locally in my application as not to mess the timeLimiter error signals, which, as the comments in the code suggest actually throw a coroutine TimeoutCancellationException.
Catching the exception and mapping it to a java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException does change the behaviour, and people currently handling CancellationExceptions should be made aware of this change.
Nevertheless, I am in favor of this change, which would also allow me to get rid of the helper function that I wrote here: #1168 (comment)
replies.author: ZzAve

replies.bodyText:
Yes, we have to document this behavior in the JavaDoc.
I think it makes sense to map TimeoutCancellationException  to a TimeoutException, if we also record it as a TimeoutException.
I guess this problem is related to issue #758

replies.bodyText:
True.
We could do
val timeoutException = TimeoutException(String.format("TimeLimiter '%s' recorded a timeout exception." , name))
timeoutException.stackTrace = t.stackTrace

We are doing a similar thing in https://github.com/resilience4j/resilience4j/blob/master/resilience4j-timelimiter/src/main/java/io/github/resilience4j/timelimiter/internal/TimeLimiterImpl.java#L52 and also add the TimeLimiter name to the exception.
I think we should match this behavior, if possible.
